TextBlock.TextLine: London Henry Collier
In Antwarp 4 Janu 16916
S I have before mee yd of 17 past. then you send yd procuration hall be delierd
to mr. Herreyns, thought if you writt him directely itt would come well
to handes for I must avoid all suspitions or TH. for I do not like their manner
of live, whoever do what you iudge conveient: I take not ice that Ben
clarck is still att grancsand I hope him over by this time 3 bylanders bang
butt of late arrived that letthim att, grancsinde: when over shall advise you
now you draw £100: againe I have accepted itt besides obliged to take in the
inclosed bill of £150 st for I have been opently blamed for drawing & redrawing
betwixt as so for feare that bill might have fullen in handes of any of them
r
have imploye m. Anneslayes mony for att present trade beeng att ostand
mony is extranagant scarey where fore have sent him my bill on you for
£80 att 2 uso att 35:6 besides £50 t payable to m. Bickering & Ropinson
att the same price & the above said £150: cost 35:9: so please to note al
accordingly hopeing & heartely wishing that you may raise so much mony
to comply with those extranagant occasions that onee I might be macondito
to remitt, or elce I can not in large that trade whilst, & wish you & al
the good familig & prosperons & happy newfeare & Remaine
In Antwerp 4 Januarij 1681
London Rikering & Robinson
to
mess. I have wel rec. yd of 17: past. inclosed you have my bill one mr. Henry
Collier for £50: att 2 uso att 35:6 as also an accomp. of sule of our 2 bal
in comp. which please to perused & finding right not accordingly & also
an acctt of the lead which will not answer attall ydexspectation, finding
that the tolles dictiss take awaij als the proffitt & the onely which ween
can exspect by that com. when wee hand itt upon our owne acctt for
then wee save those tolles, I hope you will not take itt tol ditt all
price curitt for now & never sence diditt yeald more, so wee must lett
that aside till better in corridged, as for the cloth you see the proved
I should incline for an other tryall for which shall send pattx instructions
towards sent for winter dressing is not so good whilst I am still
engaged with others in that trade shall send be glad of the opportuntio
to maintaine yd corsespondency till that time the past when
easely wee could be brick att itt for I have rec last yeare above 60 bales
from the north, butt truely in a better condition then ours were
or Elce itt should not have been to continew whoever myc
first instructions shallbe plaine then formars I hope you do
not take ill I remitt you on HC haveing occasions to draw on
him was loast to do itt otherwise to safe brouidge intrim I am
deeply engaged with the fabrick of tykes & have contantely people
att worck & can firmish the very best sorts besides am well accquainted
in the gentish legaturen so in case I can serve you in litthe
of them lease to command mee & if so be you ineline to
have the rest of yd returnes layd aut intykes for a try all I shall
do itt, so that I can afseured of a larger commission haveing send
sence I was last in England many houndred of tijkes in the
meane while wish you can happy & prosperions new yeare &
many following to content &
In antwarp 4 Januarij 1681
London Abram Vvians
th
S my last to you was on the 28. past to which please to be referred. sence held
both yd of 43„ & 27 ditto. I am glad you have Receaved the packett of laceN.5 &
that that N6&7 will be quite an otherthing N6 shal proves better then N4
truely beeng now in afar better way exspect that N6 & 7 will be guite an other
thing N6 shall be sent next post to newport to mr. michiel wallego N. 7 shall
keep t'ill I have the broad law you desire, for which I have given the necessary
order thought you desire for which I have given the nessesary order thought
you do not mention if itt must be tyoullesor without ground the
acctt. of these 2 packetts shall send p. next whilst I do exspect those from
you that come to han des about our concernes in the north I am now a
makeing op our acctt. of sales & & cctt. curitt which will be ready very speedly
& sent you trade is now att astand & mony exceeding searey, as ordinary this
time of yeare where fore you can not exspect very great returnes
before spring whoever be confident that nothing is wanting on my side
to promote he concernes, & shall remitt as soone ascomes in whilst here
cor
inclosed you have a bill on. mr guill fam son- for £150: duer3
for which please to give my acctt. creditt pray end that bussynes of
mr. Cole of the £250 for itt is un reasonable that he will not allow
itt mee up on acctt. & you neither truly I payd itt & rtter must bowitt
of both you of which long to have yd advise & so wish you an happy
succes full new yeare with many following agood Brve boy to yd ladys
In Antweere 4 Janu 81
London Arthur Annes Lay
In answer to yd of 20: past Ben klarck is not yett tariued butt I hope
that this south resterly wind shall bring him over of which shall advvise
you the needfull, as also advise how I shall finde the goods sent by him
inclosed you have my bill for £80 st on mr. Henry Collier att 2 uso
d
for which please to give yd acctt. creditt att 35:6 yd acctt. of sale is made
up & shall be sent you p first whilst in the meane which you please
to order mr. Ledynglan to buy for you 12 p 1½. yd white perpetuanes
of such sort as last be sent of about 60 s butt they ought to be better
this he can do with good leasure it beeng time nong then I have them
here about marck I shall take further spiculations concerning such
comoditie as I wrott you off before they selling, here most for ready
mony or att 3 uso spposing the suggar are yett pleaty & that the ships
from the straight arrivng, you shall finde severall sorts to content
of which itt would not be amiss if you did send now & then aprice
curitt b this I wish you anhappy & prosperons hew yeare & many
following & soremane
In Antwerp 4 Jun uary
th
London nathan tolroiwe
S in answer to yd of 21 past I do not know whj you complaine where I have the
greatest reason to be imsatisfied for ijd dealings, truely I did never exspect
such thing from you that Iw payd & layd out mony to buy the goods you sent & you
to demand the same valew from mee againe, where you knew that what came skort
on his accompt must come up on miyne beeng equally concerned I did not write mr. ible
that you was dead butt that some boddy told mee so which I could easely beleave for
I had advies from mr. Cole that you was sich, besides you long silence on my advise
whij: I did not accept yd bill did not a little attribute to itt whoever there fore
should not have refused to pay yd bill, had you given satisfaction to mr. Coles
for which you had time enoug sence I refused acceptance, to have don itt
before the bils was to be p. now to putt you to no more in conviency give mee yd
order & I'll remitt the the valew presently to mr Cole & what shall be dew to you by his
acctt. he will certainly repay you aggree with eack other that I be discharged with him
then shall I remitt erther to you or him according to order as for the concernes of
m. Dan vivians the fruestes of George shaw fter fhouse will have ended that affeire
bj las & not to re ferre itt to march &yd pertije is very likely to loose itt of which
Ibeleave you will heare more very speedly & so wish you an. Happy new
jeare & Remainer
